title: Australians eat more chicken than anyone in the Western world
text:
Australians are twice as likely to eat chicken than they are to eat beef and pork

Australians consume more chicken than anyone else in the Western world with the average person eating 49 kilograms per year.

The findings, released just in time for World Chicken Day today, show that Aussies are eating twice as much chicken as beef and pork, and six times more than lamb.

The results were also broken down by state, with Victoria taking the title of the biggest chicken lovers.

Australians consume more chicken than anyone else in the Western World with the average person churning through 49 kilograms per year

Queensland chicken-enthusiasts also prefer their chicken roasted, while New South Wales consumers like it barbecued.

HOW MUCH CHICKEN DO WE REALLY EAT? Most Australians eat chicken twice or more each week. The favourite part of the chicken for Australians overall is the breast, followed by the thigh, then leg and finally the wing. Our favourite place to eat chicken is at the dinner table at home, suggesting the rising home food delivery services are likely to grow in popularity. More women than men eat chicken once a day.

Western Australian men between the ages of 18 and 29 have also been outed as the biggest breast lovers in the country.

The report, named 'Chicken is King', came from a survey of 1,000 people conducted by Craveable Brands - the owner of Red Rooster, Oporto and Chicken Treat.

'Though breast meat is an all-round Aussie favourite, it's the most popular with young men from the West Coast,' said Craveable Brands CEO Brett Houldin.

'Meanwhile in Victoria, they are our biggest chicken lovers with 63 per cent eating it at least twice a week.'

According to the report, nearly two-thirds of Aussies don't bother with the age-old tradition of breaking the wishbone.

While the report claimed Australians were consuming 10 times more beef and veal than chicken by the end of World War II, Mr Houldin said chicken's rise in popularity is likely due to its affordability.

'The price of chicken has been getting more affordable whilst other meats are becoming out of reach,' Mr Houldin said.

'Between 1994 and 2017 chicken prices increased by only 26 per cent whilst lamb increased by 162 per cent and beef by 93 per cent.'
